The plant and charcoal records from Pilauco are complex, but crucial for understanding regional climate change, and so, we summarize our findings here. Although most investigations in the Lake District, Chiloe Island, and Pilauco show variability among sites before, during, and after the YD Chronozone, essentially the same forest/climate succession and environmental disruption is evident among all the records across the YD boundary (e.g. Moreno et al.
84 , and see Supplementary Information, S2 “Background: Paleoclimate and Biota”, and Supplementary Table S13 for a list of investigations in the area). More research is necessary to confirm the presence of impact-related evidence at other sites in southern Chile.
